awd_titl_txt: The Growth of Supermassive Black Holes and Their Co-evolution with Galaxies since Cosmic Dawn
awd_abstract_narration:
Supermassive black holes (SMBH) are thought to be at the center of many, if not most, galaxies.  They can provide information about how galaxies and black holes (BHs) form, and provide a laboratory for testing fundamental physics. The work proposed here will enhance our knowledge of how SMBHs form and advance our understanding of the early Universe.  The research will measure the masses of BHs in distant quasars by studying the spectra of the objects.  The work will provide constraints on the physical properties of newly-formed SMBHs.  The results will aid researchers in interpreting data from upcoming facilities such as the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST).

Through single-epoch spectroscopy, the investigators will use the technique of reverberation mapping to estimate BH mass in distant quasars.  They will significantly improve quasar BH mass estimation over a wider range of distances (hence, ages).  The statistics derived will help guide future investigations on early-stage BHs using JWST, 30-meter telescopes, and upcoming time-domain multi-object spectrograph projects.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the physical properties of rapidly growing supermassive black holes (called quasars) lingering at the center of massive galaxies in the distant Universe, as well as their co-evolution with their host galaxies across cosmic time. Using large samples of quasars and dedicated observational data, this project measured the masses of these active supermassive black holes and the properties of their host galaxies. With these data, this project delivered the first large sample of distant quasars with reliable measurements of their black hole masses beyond the local Universe. Using high-quality imaging observations from the Hubble Space Telescope of these quasars, we were able to derive detailed measurements of the stellar masses and structural properties of their host galaxies, and to constain the co-evolution between supermassive black holes and galaxies at cosmic noon. Furthemore, using dedicated spectroscopic observations of the most distant quasars born less than one billion years after the Big Bang, we were able to derive detailed characterizations of this first generation of supermassive black holes at cosmic dawn. The findings from this project laid the groundwork for more ambitious observing programs of distant quasars and their host galaxies with more powerful facilities in the near future, such as the James Webb Space Telescope. The success of this project has also led to important survey programs to continue the study of growing supermassive black holes and their co-evolution with galaxies with the same methodologies developed here.

During this project, we disseminated the acquired knowledge about supermassive black holes and their host galaxies to the public via various outreach channels. In particular, we organized an annual astronomy summer camp for middle school girls to engage them in hands-on learning of astronomy and scientific computing. This specific outreach program brings young female students to the forefront of cutting-edge astronomical research, and motivates their potential future career in the STEM field.
